title-group.article-title: Evidence for the differential co-localization of neurokinin-1 receptors with 5-HT receptor subtypes in rat forebrain

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pharmacology, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK
2Cambridgeshire and Peterborough NHS Foundation Trust, Peterborough, UK

author-notes.corresp: Sepehr Hafizi, Cambridgeshire and Peterborough NHS Foundation Trust, 53 Thorpe Road, Peterborough, PE3 6AN, UK Email: sepehr.hafizi@cpft.nhs.uk

abstract.p: Studies suggest that like selective 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT; serotonin) reuptake inhibitors, antagonists at neurokinin-1 receptors (NK1Rs) may have antidepressant and anxiolytic properties. NK1Rs are present in 5-HT innervated forebrain regions which may provide a common point of interaction between these two transmitter systems. This study aimed to investigate for cellular co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT receptor subtypes in mood-related brain regions in the rat forebrain. With experiments using fluorescence immunocytochemistry, double-labelling methods demonstrated a high degree of co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT1A receptors in most regions examined. Co-localization was highest in the medial septum (88% NK1R expressing cells were 5-HT1A receptor-positive) and hippocampal regions (e.g. dentate gyrus, 65%), followed by the lateral/basolateral amygdala (35%) and medial prefrontal cortex (31%). In contrast, co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT2A receptors was infrequent (< 8%) in most areas examined except for the hippocampus (e.g. CA3, 43%). Overall co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT1A receptors was much greater than that between NK1Rs and 5-HT2A receptors. Thus, these experiments demonstrate a high degree of co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT1A receptors in cortical and limbic regions of the rat forebrain. These findings suggest a novel site of interaction between NK1R antagonists and the 5-HT system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The neuropeptide Substance P acts via central neurokinin-1 receptors (NK1Rs) to modulate the processing of emotional and stressful stimuli (Commons, 2010; Ebner et al., 2009; Mantyh et al., 1984; Nakaya et al., 1994). Pre-clinical studies showed that Substance P and NK1R agonists induced anxiety, while NK1R antagonists exhibited anxiolytic and antidepressant properties (Commons, 2010; Papp et al., 2000; Rotzinger et al., 2010; Rupniak and Kramer, 1999). In support of these findings, NK1R knockout mice displayed marked reductions in anxiety and stress-related behaviours (Santarelli et al., 2001).

An initial phase II clinical trial in depression showed the NK1R antagonist aprepitant (MK-869) to be more effective than placebo and as effective as the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, paroxetine (Kramer et al., 1998). Although this was not borne out in a larger trial (Keller et al., 2006), the antidepressant and anxiolytic efficacy of the NK1R antagonist L-759,274 was confirmed in a further phase II trial (Kramer et al., 2004). Through this link with mood disorders, a recent study also investigated the role of NK1Rs in alcoholism (George et al., 2008). The study used a randomized placebo controlled experimental design to show that the NK1R antagonist LY686017 could suppress cravings for alcohol in recently detoxified alcoholic patients. Analogous effects of LY686017 were also seen with brain functional magnetic resonance imaging on responses to affective stimuli (George et al., 2008). However, further studies are required to confirm the role of NK1Rs in the treatment of alcohol dependence (Heilig et al., 2010).

A human post-mortem brain study showed decreased NK1R numbers in orbitofrontal cortical regions of depressed patients (Stockmeier et al., 2002). Another study observed a lowered ratio of superficial to deep laminar binding for NK1Rs in the anterior cingulate cortex in depression (Burnet and Harrison, 2000), while another post-mortem study did not show a difference in NK1R binding in the amygdala in depression (Carletti et al., 2005).

In addition to the clinical trials noted above, other studies have implicated the neurokinin system in anxiety. For example, in one study Substance P levels were found to be elevated in the cerebrospinal fluid of patients with post-traumatic stress disorder (Geracioti et al., 2006). A more recent positron emission tomography study showed NK1R numbers to be reduced in patients with a history of panic disorder (Fujimura et al., 2009), and NK1R antagonists have been investigated for their role in social phobia (Furmark et al., 2005) and specific phobias (Michelgard et al., 2007).

There is a well-established link between depression, anxiety disorders and 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT; serotonin), and a number of studies suggest that NK1Rs interact with the 5-HT system (Blier et al., 2004; Commons et al., 2003; Conley et al., 2002; Lacoste et al., 2006; Maubach et al., 2002). Many of these studies have explored this interaction in mood regulating regions such as the midbrain raphe and locus coeruleus. For example, Substance P infused in vivo into the dorsal raphe nuclei was associated with decreased 5-HT cell firing (Valentino et al., 2003), while NK1R deletion (Conley et al., 2002; Santarelli et al., 2001) and NK1R antagonists increased neuronal firing in dorsal raphe nuclei (Haddjeri and Blier, 2001). Interestingly, NK1R-/- mice also showed 5-HT1A somatodendritic autoreceptor desensitization (Froger et al., 2001), similar to chronic treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (Riad et al., 2004) and the NK1R antagonist GR-205,171 (Guiard et al., 2005). Furthermore, recent studies have also localized NK1Rs to a subpopulation of 5-HT neurons in the dorsal raphe (Lacoste et al., 2006, 2009). In addition, the effects of modulation of NK1Rs on 5-HT levels in the cortex have been studied. For example, intracerebral in vivo microdialysis has shown that increases in cortical 5-HT overflow caused by paroxetine were higher in freely moving NK1R-/- mutants than in wild-type mice (Herpfer et al., 2005), and that administration of the NK1R antagonist GR-205,171 to wild-type mice potentiated paroxetine-induced increases in cortical 5-HT dialysate (Guiard et al., 2005).

In other studies NK1R antagonists increased the firing rate of noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus (Maubach et al., 2002). In addition, a reciprocal interaction has been shown between the dorsal raphe nucleus and the locus coeruleus (Gobbi et al., 2007). Both the genetic deletion and pharmacological blockade of NK1Rs increased 5-HT neuronal firing (Gobbi et al., 2007), but this increase was mediated by noradrenergic neurons: in fact a selective lesion of the noradrenergic neurons prevented the enhancement of 5-HT firing activity by NK1RAs (Gobbi et al., 2007).

A recent study explored the effects of NK1Rs in the lateral septum and the interaction with 5-HT (Ebner et al., 2008). The investigators found that acute administration of NK1R antagonist L-822429 into the lateral septum reduced stress coping strategies in the forced swim test, and that this effect may be modulated by 5-HT1A receptors. Immunocytochemical experiments in the lateral septum showed NK1Rs localized to calbindin-positive neurons, suggesting that NK1R antagonists may influence 5-HT transmission indirectly via gamma-amino butyric acid (GABA) (Ebner et al., 2008).

Despite the above, little is known about the anatomical interaction of the NK1R and 5-HT systems at the level of the forebrain. Indeed, the levels of NK1Rs are high in some brain regions that receive 5-HT innervations from the midbrain raphe nuclei including the prefrontal cortex, septum, hippocampus and amygdala (Barnes and Sharp, 1999; Nakaya et al., 1994). In these regions, 5-HT acts via a diversity of postsynaptic 5-HT receptor subtypes, including 5-HT1A receptors (5-HT1ARs) and 5-HT2A receptors (5-HT2ARs), which are known to be important in the aetiology of depression and the mechanism of action of antidepressants (Santarelli et al., 2003; Sargent et al., 2000; Stockmeier, 2003). It is notable that regions which are abundant in 5-HT1ARs, such as the septum, hippocampus and frontal and entorhinal cortices, are also abundant in NK1Rs (Aznar et al., 2003; Clement et al., 1996; Kia et al., 1996c; Pompeiano et al., 1992; Wright et al., 1995). Similarly, 5-HT2ARs are distributed in the olfactory region, striatum, cortex, hippocampus and amygdala, which also contain NK1Rs (Cornea-Hebert et al., 1999; Xu and Pandey, 2000). Thus, NK1Rs and major 5-HT receptor subtypes are found in similar regions in the forebrain, which may represent a potential site of interaction between NK1R antagonists, the 5-HT system and the modulation of mood.

The present study used double-labelling immunofluorescent microscopy to investigate the degree of cellular co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT1ARs and 5-HT2ARs in rat forebrain regions including the prefrontal cortex, septum, hippocampus and amygdala.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (Harlan-Olac, Bicester, UK) were housed in cages in a temperature-controlled environment with a 12 h light/dark cycle (lights on at 07:00) and allowed free access to food and water. Animal experiments were carried out according to Home Office guidelines and UK Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986, and were designed to minimize animal suffering and number of animals used.

sec.title: 5-HT receptor and NK1 receptor co-localization
sec.p: One group of six adult rats (250–370 g) were examined for NK1R and 5-HT1AR co-localization, while in a separate experiment a second group of six adult rats (230–250 g) were examined for NK1R and 5-HT2AR co-localization. Rats were deeply anaesthetized with intraperitoneal sodium pentobarbital (Merial Animal Health Ltd, Harlow, UK; 200 mg/kg) and transcardially perfused with 200 ml buffer (0.9% saline for 5-HT1AR; phosphate buffer for 5-HT2AR) followed by about 300 ml of ice-cold fixative composed of 4% (w/v) paraformaldehyde (Agar Scientific, Stansted, UK) and 0.4% (v/v) saturated aqueous picric acid in 0.1 M phosphate buffer at pH 6.9 for 20 min.

For the NK1R and 5-HT1AR co-localization experiment, the brains were removed and post-fixed in the above solution overnight at 4°C. Brains were then cut into smaller blocks before sectioning. Coronal sections (40 µm) were prepared using a vibrating microtome (Leica, Milton Keynes, UK) at rostrocaudal bregma levels of 2.70 mm, 0.70 mm and −3.30 mm according to the Paxinos and Watson atlas (see Figure 1) (Paxinos and Watson, 1998). The sections were collected as free-floating sections in ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, pH 7.4, components 0.14 M sodium chloride, 0.003 M potassium chloride, 0.01 M phosphate buffer) and after washes in PBS, stored at 4°C in PBS with 0.1% (w/v) sodium azide preservative. Following washes in PBS, sections were incubated for 90 min at room temperature in blocking buffer composed of 0.3% (v/v) Triton X-100, 10% (v/v) normal goat serum and 1% (w/v) bovine serum albumin in PBS, and then incubated overnight at 4°C with rabbit NK1R (Chemicon, CA, USA; 1:2000; AB5060) and guinea pig 5-HT1AR primary antibodies (Chemicon; 1:1000; AB5406). The sections were then washed in PBS followed by incubation in Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-rabbit (Molecular Probes, Netherlands; 1:1000) and Alexa Fluor 568 goat anti-guinea pig secondary antibodies (Molecular Probes; 1:500) for 4 h at room temperature, while protected from light. All anti-sera were diluted in PBS, 0.3% Triton X-100, 1% normal goat serum and 1% bovine serum albumin. After further washes, sections were mounted from a buffer bath onto gelatine-coated glass slides, allowed to air-dry while protected from light before being cover-slipped with Vectashield liquid mounting medium (Vector Laboratories, Peterborough, UK). Controls included omitting the primary antibody as well as comparisons for cross-reactivity between a primary antibody and the unrelated secondary antibody.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of coronal rat forebrain sections with regions examined for co-localization. Brain regions examined were: the infralimbic (IL) and the prelimbic (PL) regions combined to represent the prefrontal cortex; FCx represents the frontal cortex (bregma 2.70 mm); the septum (medial septum and diagonal band of Broca complex (MS) and lateral septum (LS) (bregma 0.70 mm); the hippocampal sub-regions (dentate gyrus [DG], CA1 and CA3) and amygdala (lateral and basolateral aspects [LA/BLA]) (bregma −3.30 mm). Percentage co-localization of NK1 and 5-HT receptors illustrated as quintiles: (A) NK1R and 5-HT1AR; (B) NK1R and 5-HT2AR. 5-HT1AR: 5-HT1A receptors, 5-HT2AR: 5-HT2A receptors, NK1R: NK1 receptors. (Adapted from Paxinos G and Watson C (1998) The Rat Brain in Streretaxic Coordinates with permission from Elsevier).

sec.p: For the NK1R and 5-HT2AR co-localization experiment, the process was as described above with minor differences. Brains were post-fixed at 4°C for 4 h and then transferred for about 36 h to 30% (w/v) sucrose in PBS for cryoprotection at 4°C. Coronal sections (30 µm) were then collected via a freezing sliding microtome (Leica Microsystems, Germany). Incubation with monoclonal mouse 5-HT2AR primary antibody (Pharmingen; 1:1000; #556326) was for three nights at 4°C, with rabbit NK1R primary antibody (Chemicon; 1:2000) added on the final night. The secondary antibody used for 5-HT2AR was Alexa Fluor 568 goat anti-mouse antibody (Molecular Probes; 1:1000).

sec.title: Fluorescence microscopy and histological analysis
sec.p: Tissue sections were initially examined using a Leitz Diaplan microscope (Leica, Germany) fitted with an incident 50 Watt mercury arc lamp and equipped with epifluorescence optics and dichroic filters and viewed via a Leitz PL-Fluotar objective (× 40 numerical aperture = 0.7). Filters used were as follows: green fluorophore 420–490 excitation band-pass and 520 nm emission long-pass; red fluorophore 530–560 nm excitation band-pass and 580 nm emission long-pass.

Cell counts were collected at × 40 objective throughout. Cell counting was carried out on sections from the prefrontal cortex (prelimbic plus infralimbic regions), frontal cortex (regions M1 and M2), lateral septum (bilaterally) and medial septum including the diagonal band of Broca, amygdala (lateral and basolateral combined) and hippocampus (dentate gyrus, CA1, CA3). Cell counts for co-localized NK1R immunoreactivity (-ir) and 5-HT receptor-ir were made bilaterally on three sections, which were collected alternately to avoid counting the same cells twice. All NK1R-ir positive cells were counted in defined anatomical areas according to the Paxinos and Watson atlas (see Figure 1) (Paxinos and Watson, 1998). Percentage co-localization is presented as mean of six brains +/− standard error of the mean.

Digital images of sections with NK1R-ir and 5-HT1AR-ir double-labelling were captured using a cooled colour CCD camera (model C4742-95; Hamamatsu, Welwyn Garden City, UK) on a Leica (Wetzlar, Germany) DMRB microscope with epifluorescence illumination equipped with the following filter blocks: A4 (excitation filter band-pass, 360/40 nm; reflection short-pass filter, 400 nm; suppression filter band-pass, 470/40 nm), L5 (excitation filter band-pass, 480/40 nm; reflection short-pass filter, 505 nm; suppression filter band-pass, 527/30 nm), Y3 (excitation filter band-pass, 545/30 nm; reflection short-pass filter, 565 nm; suppression filter band-pass, 610/75 nm), and Y5 (excitation filter band-pass, 620/60 nm; reflection short-pass filter, 660 nm; suppression filter B-P, 700/75 nm). Coloured digital images of sections with NK1R-ir and 5-HT2AR-ir double-labelling were obtained using a Xillix Micro Imager camera (Xillix Technologies Corp., Canada) on the Leitz Diaplan microscope described above.

Images were analysed and displayed using Openlab software (version 3.1.4; Improvision, Coventry, UK). Brightness and contrast were adjusted for the entire frame, and no part of a frame was modified in any way. Digital images were manipulated with regards to size, cropping, colour balance, brightness using Photoshop 5.0 software (Adobe systems, San Jose, CA, USA) on a Power Macintosh computer and later labelled using Powerpoint (Microsoft).

sec.title: Distribution of NK1 receptor immunoreactivity
sec.p: NK1R-ir was detected throughout the forebrain, and showed a regional distribution similar to that shown previously (Nakaya et al., 1994). As with previous studies, NK1R-ir was most predominantly observed on the cell membranes of neuronal somata and fibres (Chen et al., 2001; Hahn and Bannon, 1999). Strong expression for NK1R-ir was present on cell membranes in all parts of the medial septum-diagonal band of Broca complex (Figures 2A, 2C, 2E, 2G). NK1R-ir was also observed on cells and fibres in hippocampal sub-regions. In the dentate gyrus in particular, strong expression of NK1R-ir was seen on a network of fibres (Figure 3A). NK1R-ir was less dense in the basolateral amygdala and the medial prefrontal cortex (Figures 3E, 3G).

caption.p: Photomicrographs of NK1 and 5-HT1A receptor immunoreactivities in medial septum and vertical diagonal band of Broca. Higher magnification photographs of the square in A + B are shown in C, D and C + D. 5-HT1AR-ir and NK1R-ir cell bodies are observed in the medial septum (MS) (C, D and C + D). Similarly, higher magnification photographs of the square in E + F are shown in G, H and G + H. 5-HT1AR-ir and NK1R-ir cell bodies are observed in the vertical diagonal band of Broca (VDBB) (G, H and G + H). Cells co-localized for NK1R-ir and 5-HT1AR-ir are observed in the MS (arrows in C, D, C + D), and the VDBB (arrows in G, H and G + H). Scale bars: A + B, 120 µm; C + D, 30 µm; E + F, 120 µm; G + H, 30 µm.

Photomicrographs of NK1 and 5-HT1A receptor immunoreactivities in dentate gyrus of hippocampus and prelimbic region of the prefrontal cortex. In the dentate gyrus, lower magnification photomicrographs reveal extensive NK1R-ir in fibres (A) and extensive 5-HT1AR-ir in cell bodies (B) in the dentate gyrus. Higher magnification photographs of the square in A + B are shown in C, D and C + D. The cell arrowed (C, D, C + D) shows co-localization for NK1R-ir and 5- HT1AR-ir (C + D). In the prefrontal cortex, lower magnification photomicrographs reveal sparse NK1R-ir in cell bodies with extensive NK1R-ir in fibres (E) and weak, but extensive 5-HT1AR-ir in cell bodies (F). Higher magnification photographs of the square in E + F are shown in G, H and G + H. A cell co-localizing NK1R-ir and 5-HT1AR-ir is observed (arrowed in G, H and G + H). Scale bars: A + B, 120 µm; C + D, 30 µm; E + F, 60 µm; G + H, 30 µm.

sec.title: Distribution of 5-HT1A receptor immunoreactivity
sec.p: 5-HT1AR-ir was detected throughout the rat forebrain regions studied, and this followed the pattern observed previously (Collin et al., 2002; Kia et al., 1996a, 1996b, 1996c; Luttgen et al., 2005; Martin-Ruiz et al., 2001; Ou et al., 2003). As in the other studies, 5-HT1AR-ir was predominantly seen in cell soma and only occasionally in dendrites. 5-HT1AR-ir was prominent on cells in midline and lateral zones of the medial septum (Figures 2B, 2D) and in the diagonal band of Broca (Figures 2F, 2H). 5-HT1AR-ir was also abundant in hippocampal dentate gyrus (Figure 3B), but with prominent immunoreactivity in hilar regions and only faint 5-HT1AR-ir within the granule cell layer. Abundant 5-HT1AR-ir was also observed in hippocampal CA1 and CA3 as well as the basolateral amygdala, prefrontal cortex (Figures 3F, 3H) and frontal cortex.

sec.title: Distribution of 5-HT2A receptor immunoreactivity
sec.p: 5-HT2AR-ir was detected throughout the rat forebrain in concordance with previous reports (Luttgen et al., 2004; Wu et al., 1998; Xu and Pandey, 2000) and was distinct from that of 5-HT1AR-ir. Here, the cellular distribution of 5-HT2AR-ir showed a predominantly somatodendritic neuronal localization as has been previously described (Martin-Ruiz et al., 2001; Miner et al., 2003; Nocjar et al., 2002). Cellular expression of 5-HT2AR-ir was observed in the medial septum and diagonal band of Broca, the hippocampus, e.g. CA3 (Figure 4B), and basolateral amygdala. Within the prefrontal cortex, 5-HT2AR-ir was prominent on both cell bodies and fibres.

caption.p: Photomicrographs of NK1 and 5-HT2A receptor immunoreactivities in CA3 region of hippocampus. Higher magnification photomicrographs of the square in A + B are shown in C, D and C + D. Cells co-localizing NK1R-ir and 5-HT2AR-ir are observed (arrowed in C, D and C + D). Cells with only NK1R-ir are also observed (arrowheads in C and C + D). so: Stratum oriens, sp: Stratum pyramidale, sr: Stratum radiatum. Scale bars: A + B, 80 µm; C + D, 50 µm.

sec.title: NK1 and 5-HT1A receptor co-localization
sec.p: In this study, the brain regions rich in NK1R-ir were also rich in 5-HT1AR-ir. Cellular co-localization between NK1R-ir and 5-HT1AR-ir was frequent in most areas examined. The highest percentage of co-localization was present in medial septum-diagonal band of Broca complex (88.0%), dentate gyrus (65.1%) and CA3 regions (62.5%). Moderate co-localization was seen in the basolateral amygdala (34.5%), hippocampal CA1 region (32.4%), frontal cortex (32.0%) and prefrontal cortex (31.1%). Very little co-localization (3.9%) was found in the lateral septum (see Table 1 and Figure 1A). Figure 2 depicts 5-HT1AR-ir and NK1R-ir co-localization on neurons in the medial septum (Figures 2, C + D) and vertical diagonal band of Broca (Figures 2, G + H), whilst Figure 3 depicts co-localization in the dentate gyrus (Figures 3C, 3D) and the prefrontal cortex (Figures 3, G + H).

caption.p: NK1 and 5-HT1A receptor co-localization in rat forebrain

fn.p: The total number of NK1R-ir cells counted (total from all animals) and the number of cells also immunoreactive for 5-HT1ARs is tabulated together with the mean (SEM) percentage co-localization in different brain regions; in each brain region cell counts were made from both hemispheres in three slices for each brain (total of six brains). aInfralimbic/prelimbic regions only. bM1 and M2 regions combined. cBoth hemispheres counted together as one in the septal areas. dLateral/basolateral amygdala only. eCA4 not included as part of the dentate gyrus.

sec.title: NK1 and 5-HT2A receptor co-localization
sec.p: Co-localization between NK1R-ir and 5-HT2AR-ir was infrequent (< 8%) in most areas except for hippocampus: dentate gyrus (15.9%), CA1 (24.8%) and CA3 (43.1%) as shown in Table 2 and illustrated in Figure 1B. An example of 5-HT2AR-ir and NK1R-ir co-localization is depicted on CA3 neurons in Figure 4, C + D.

caption.p: NK1 and 5-HT2A receptor co-localization in rat forebrain

fn.p: The total number of NK1R-ir cells counted (total from all animals) and the number of cells also immunoreactive for 5-HT2ARs is tabulated together with the mean (SEM) percentage co-localization in different brain regions; in each brain region cell counts were made from both hemispheres in three slices for each brain (total of six brains). aInfralimbic/prelimbic regions only. bM1 and M2 regions combined. cBoth hemispheres counted together as one in the septal areas. dLateral/basolateral amygdala only. eCA4 not included as part of the dentate gyrus.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Previous studies report the presence of NK1Rs in brain regions that receive 5-HT innervations from the midbrain dorsal and median raphe nuclei (Barnes and Sharp, 1999; Nakaya et al., 1994). However, it was not known whether NK1Rs and 5-HT receptor subtypes co-localize on the same cells. The aim of the current study was to search for evidence of co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT1ARs, and between NK1Rs and 5-HT2ARs in the rat forebrain. This interaction may be important with regards to the antidepressant action of NK1R antagonists.

The main findings of the present study were: (1) NK1R-ir and 5-HT1AR-ir were co-localized to a high degree in many forebrain regions, in particular the medial septum-diagonal band of Broca complex and hippocampus. Co-localization was also present in prefrontal cortex, frontal cortex and lateral and basolateral amygdala, but to a lesser degree. (2) NK1R-ir was found to co-localize with 5-HT2ARs in hippocampal sub-regions, but not in other areas investigated. (3) The degree of co-localization between NK1R and 5-HT1ARs was much greater than that between NK1R and 5-HT2ARs.

The primary antibodies used in the current study have been validated in previous work. The NK1R antibody (C-terminal amino acids 385–407; rabbit) was shown to provide specific labelling (Commons et al., 2003; Lacoste et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2002; Myohanen et al., 2008; Nakaya et al., 1994; Shigemoto et al., 1993). In pre-adsorption tests, excess of the fusion protein containing the NK1R C-terminal completely blocked immunoreactivity (Piggins et al., 2001; Shigemoto et al., 1993), while in another study, polyclonal rabbit anti-NK1R serum specifically recognized a broad protein band on Western blots of membranes prepared from cells expressing NK1R (Vigna et al., 1994). In addition, antibody specificity has been tested by the processing of sections from NK1R knockout mice (Lacoste et al., 2006). Furthermore, in our study, control experiments where the primary antibody was excluded did not result in any labelling.

The specificity of the guinea-pig polyclonal 5-HT1AR antibody used in our study has been confirmed when preabsorption of 5-HT1AR antiserum with immunogen peptide (10−5 M) corresponding to amino acids 248–262 located within the third intracellular loop of the rat 5-HT1AR and the hapten thyroglobulin (0.5 mg/µl undiluted antiserum) resulted in marked reduction in immunostaining (Collin et al., 2002; Luttgen et al., 2005). The pattern of immunohistochemical staining found in our study was similar to those found in other studies when using the same antibody in the same brain regions (Collin et al., 2002; Luttgen et al., 2005; Ou et al., 2003). As in the other studies, 5-HT1AR-ir was predominantly seen in cell soma and occasionally also seen in dendrites.

In our study, 5-HT1AR-ir within the dentate gyrus was prominent in hilar regions, but faint in the granule cell layer, and other investigators have found similar results with other polyclonal anti-5-HT1AR antibodies (Gerard et al., 1994; Kia et al., 1996c; Kim et al., 2007). However, some other studies using a polyclonal rabbit antibody to the third intracellular loop (amino acids 258–274) (Aznar et al., 2003) or an antibody raised against the second extracellular loop of the 5-HT1AR (amino acids 170-186) (Patel et al., 1996) did detect 5-HT1AR-ir in hippocampal principal cells including the granule cell layer. Similarly, in the lateral septum, the current study found only weak immunostaining for 5-HT1AR in neurons, in concordance with one study (Luttgen et al., 2005), while another study reported strong somatodendritic staining in this region (Kia et al., 1996c). Different staining patterns from the use of different antibodies may be related to differences in the epitopes recognized by the antibodies. For example, it may be that the antibody recognizing the binding site of the 5-HT1AR (amino acids 170-186) will mostly only allow for the visualization of functionally active membrane-bound receptors, and is less likely to allow for the visualization of cytoplasmic receptors that may be in the process of synthesis or degradation (Anthony and Azmitia, 1997; Azmitia et al., 1992; Czyrak et al., 2003). However, no differences in staining patterns have been found in the hippocampus with regards to GABA neurons. Thus any differences in staining patterns on principal cells would not have a bearing on the results of our study. This is because NK1Rs are found only in GABA neurons within the rat hippocampus (Acsady et al., 1997; Sloviter et al., 2001).

The 5-HT2AR antibody used in our study (Wu et al., 1998) was a monoclonal mouse antiserum generated against a recombinant hybridoma fusion protein between glutathione S-transferase (GST) and the first extracellular domain of the human 5-HT2AR (amino acids 1–72 of the amino terminus). The hybridomas were screened by Pharmingen using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, immunocytochemistry of frozen rat brain sections, and Western blot analysis: the 5-HT2AR antibody recognized the receptor as a 55-kDa band. The specificity of the band was verified by competition with a 5-HT2AR fusion protein and lack of competition with an irrelevant fusion protein. The supernatant was also tested against GST protein to rule out reactivity to this part of the immunogen. The antibody was purified from hybridoma culture supernatant by protein G affinity chromatography. In addition, the antibody has specifically been shown to react with human, monkey and rat 5-HT2AR (Jakab and Goldman-Rakic, 1998). Other investigators confirmed the specificity of the antibody by Western blot analysis of rat brain membranes, human brain and transfected NIH 3T3 cell lysates, and immunofluorescence of rat Schwann cells in culture (Wu et al., 1998; Xu and Pandey, 2000). The antisera utilized have been characterized and applied in brain tissues, with specificity of labelling demonstrated in many different studies (Cornea-Hebert et al., 1999; Doherty and Pickel, 2000; Garlow et al., 1993; Jakab and Goldman-Rakic, 1998, 2000; Jansson et al., 1998, 2001; Luttgen et al., 2004; McDonald and Mascagni, 2007; Martin-Ruiz et al., 2001; Miner et al., 2003; Willins et al., 1999; Wu et al., 1998; Xu and Pandey, 2000).

The distribution and somatodendritic labelling of 5-HT2AR-ir observed here was as demonstrated in many different studies (Cornea-Hebert et al., 1999; Garlow et al., 1993; Jakab and Goldman-Rakic, 1998; Luttgen et al., 2004; Martin-Ruiz et al., 2001). As in a previous study, 5-HT2AR-ir was detected in cell bodies within the septum, cells located in the pyramidal cell layers CA1-3 of the hippocampus and in the granular cell layer of the dentate gyrus as well as hippocampal interneurons (Luttgen et al., 2004). 5-HT2AR-ir was also observed in the basolateral amygdala in cell bodies and some neuronal fibres as seen before (Xu and Pandey, 2000). Within the cerebral cortex, 5-HT2AR was highly expressed with particular staining of cell bodies and apical dendrites of pyramidal neurons (Wu et al., 1998).

For practical purposes only a limited number of brain regions were examined in this study. Also, it should be noted that as NK1R-positive neurons were generally sparse (except in the septum) cells were counted across whole anatomical areas rather than by using intra-region grids. As a consequence, although the percentage co-localization across regions can be compared, the data are not amenable to statistical comparisons.

A key finding of the present study was that NK1R-ir and 5-HT1AR-ir were co-localized to a high degree in all regions examined except for the lateral septum, with the degree of co-localization ranging from 88% (medial septum) to 31% (medial prefrontal cortex) of cells labelled with NK1R-ir in these regions. Although the study did not attempt to establish the chemical identity of the cells demonstrating co-localization of NK1Rs and 5-HT1ARs, this is likely to vary depending on the brain region investigated. In particular, it is likely that NK1Rs and 5-HT1ARs are co-localized on GABAergic neurons within the hippocampus, amygdala and medial prefrontal cortex. This is because although 5-HT1ARs are located on GABAergic neurons and pyramidal neurons within these regions (Aznar et al., 2003; Gulyas et al., 1999), NK1Rs are found only on GABAergic neurons in the hippocampus (Acsady et al., 1997; Freund and Buzsaki, 1996; Sloviter et al., 2001), basolateral amygdala (Levita et al., 2003) and prefrontal cortex (Kaneko et al., 1994). On the other hand, it is likely that NK1Rs and 5-HT1ARs are co-localized on cholinergic neurons in the medial septum-diagonal band of Broca complex. This is because, although 5-HT1ARs are found on cholinergic neurons (Kia et al., 1996a) as well as GABAergic neurons (Aznar et al., 2003) within the medial septum-diagonal band of Broca complex, NK1Rs are found only on cholinergic neurons within this region (Chen et al., 2001).

Compared with NK1Rs and 5-HT1ARs, the degree of co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT2ARs was much less common, and this co-localization may be restricted to GABAergic neurons. This is evidenced by the fact that NK1Rs are found on GABAergic neurons within the hippocampus and amygdala, whilst 5-HT2ARs are found on GABAergic cells as well as dendrites of excitatory granule cells within the hippocampus (Geurts et al., 2002; Jakab and Goldman-Rakic, 2000; Luttgen et al., 2004; Meltzer et al., 2003; Peddie et al., 2008) and dendrites of pyramidal cells in the basolateral amygdala (Cornea-Hebert et al., 1999; McDonald and Mascagni, 2007; Morilak et al., 1993; Xu and Pandey, 2000).

Given the high degree of NK1R and 5-HT1AR co-localization, it is interesting that these receptors have opposing functions at the signalling level. Thus, NK1Rs are positively coupled to phospholipase C (Hamke et al., 2006; Mitsuhashi et al., 1992; Nakajima et al., 1992; Satake and Kawada, 2006) and excite neurons (Page, 2005; Pennefather et al., 2004), whereas 5-HT1ARs are negatively coupled to adenylate cyclase and hyperpolarize neurons through opening G-protein-coupled K+ channels (Barnes and Sharp, 1999; Hoyer et al., 2002). In comparison, NK1Rs and 5-HT2ARs have complementary functions at the signalling level with 5-HT2ARs, like NK1Rs, being positively coupled to phospholipase C and bringing about neuronal excitation (see Barnes and Sharp, 1999).

The above predicts that 5-HT1AR agonists, NK1R antagonists and 5-HT2AR antagonists may have similar functional effects and there is both electrophysiological and behavioural evidence to support this. For example, the 5-HT1AR agonist 8-OH-DPAT inhibited the firing rate of hippocampal neurons (Stein et al., 2000; Wang et al., 1999), whereas the NK1R antagonist SR140,333 suppressed Substance P-induced excitation of hippocampal neurons (Dreifuss and Raggenbass, 1986; Teixeira et al., 1996). Also, local infusions of 5-HT1AR agonists into the septum reversed helpless behaviour on the learned helplessness paradigm (Martin et al., 1991) and the forced swim test (Schreiber and De Vry, 1993). The latter study specifically investigated infusions into the lateral septum. A more recent study showed that local administration of the NK1R antagonist L-822429 into the lateral septum reduced passive and facilitated active stress-coping strategies in the forced swim test (Ebner et al., 2008). The investigators suggested that this effect was mediated via increased 5-HT neurotransmission as it was blocked by intraseptal 5-HT1AR antagonism. They also showed that NK1Rs were located on calbindin-positive neurons, suggesting the involvement of GABAergic interneurons in this interaction (Ebner et al., 2008). In concordance with the results of the latter study, we did not find significant co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT1ARs in the lateral septum in our study. However, we suggest that the high percentage of co-localization in the medial septum is worth further investigation as functional studies with NK1R antagonists in this brain region may show much more powerful effects than those observed in the lateral septum.

Studies in the amygdala showed that local infusions of 5-HT1AR agonists into the basolateral amygdala had anxiolytic effects as measured on the elevated T-maze (Zangrossi et al., 1999), and the contextual conditioned freezing test (Li et al., 2006). Similar observations of anxiolysis have been made following local infusion of 5-HT2R antagonists (Hodges et al., 1987) or NK1R antagonists (Boyce et al., 2001; Ebner and Singewald, 2006).

The above animal studies resonate with the findings of the clinical effects of 5-HT1AR agonists, NK1R antagonists and 5-HT2AR antagonists. For example, initial phase II trials showed benefits over placebo for NK1R antagonist aprepitant (Kramer et al., 1998) with antidepressant efficacy also being observed with the NK1R antagonists L-759274 (Compound A) (Kramer et al., 2004) and CP-122721 (Chappell, 2002). In a similar way, the 5-HT1AR agonist buspirone (Rush et al., 2009) and atypical antipsychotics with 5-HT2R blocking properties (Fontaine, 1993; Millan, 2003; Olver et al., 2008) have been shown to effectively augment the action of antidepressants.

In conclusion, the present study observed significant degrees of co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT1ARs in rat forebrain regions, as well as a more restricted level of co-localization between NK1Rs and 5-HT2ARs. These results suggest a novel cellular substrate for interactions between NK1R antagonists and the 5-HT system. On the basis of known signalling effects of NK1Rs, 5-HT1ARs and 5-HT2ARs, there is an interesting prediction that NK1R antagonists might have similar functional effects to 5-HT1AR agonists and 5-HT2AR antagonists, and there is evidence to support this in some preclinical and clinical studies.

sec.p: This work was supported by the Medical Research Council (UK) with a Clinical Research Training Fellowship to SH.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
